newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Vanuatu calm after president abducted, released.
newsitem.headline: Vanuatu calm after president abducted, released.

text.p: The South Pacific island nation of Vanuatu was reported calm on Saturday after a group of paramilitary police abducted, then released, the president and the acting prime minister over a pay dispute.

Paramilitary police abducted President Jean-Marie Leye just after dawn, commandeered a plane and flew him to a neighbouring island where they met acting prime minister Barak Sope who was there on business, Australian Broadcasting Corp radio reported.
They returned the two to the capital, Port Vila, demanding an immediate cabinet meeting.
The cabinet agreed to resolve the dispute, which was over overtime pay arrears of about US$150,000, ABC reported.
A producer at Radio Vanuatu in the capital, Port Vila, told Reuters by telephone that the country was peaceful.
"I think from now on the situation will go back to normal, there's no problem at all, and it's okay," a spokesman said.
"Nobody was hurt and everything is okay."
An Australian foreign affairs official also said the situation seemed to be under control and all was reported to be calm. No injuries were reported, he said.
The paramilitary forces have been on strike for two weeks over the pay claim.
The 80-island nation has been embroiled in a political crisis since the last election in November 1995, when no party won a majority in the 50-seat parliament.
The government of Maxime Carlot was toppled in September when parliament passed a vote of no confidence.
Serge Vohor, the only candidate, was elected prime minister.
Vohor was visiting French Polynesia on Saturday.
Vanuatu, with a population of about 145,000, was formerly known as the New Hebrides and was governed jointly by Britain and France until independence in 1980.
